item.title: Trump Rattles Markets With Fresh Tariff Threats on EU, Apple
item.description: President Donald Trump threatened a sweeping 50% tariff on the European Union and a 25% levy on Apple Inc. if the tech giant failed to move iPhone manufacturing to the US, reigniting investor fears about his trade agenda.
item.dc:creator: Skylar Woodhouse

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump Photographer: Bonnie Cash/UPI

item.title: Trump Lauds ‘Major’ Prisoner Swap Between Ukraine and Russia
item.description: US President Donald Trump said Russia and Ukraine had carried out a “major” prisoner swap, lauding the move as a sign of progress as his efforts to broker an agreement to end the war have faltered.
item.dc:creator: Aliaksandr Kudrytski, Moira Warburton

media:content.media:description: Ukrainian, American and Russian delegates meet for Ukraine-Russia peace talks at the office of Turkish President, in an image provided by Turkish Foreign Ministry, in Istanbul, Turkey, on May 16.

item.title: Trump Threatens 25% Tariffs on Apple If iPhones Not Made in US
item.description: President Donald Trump threatened Apple Inc. with a tariff of at least 25% if it does not manufacture its iPhones in the US, ramping up pressure on the tech giant to secure more domestic production.
item.dc:creator: Skylar Woodhouse, Mark Gurman

media:content.media:description: An advertisement for an Apple iPhone. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: China Gives EU Business Groups High-Level Meetings
item.description: China is giving European business leaders its warmest welcome in years, in an effort to strengthen ties as Beijing seeks to counter Donald Trump’s tariff pressure and stabilize its slowing economy.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Choong Wilkins, Colum Murphy, Jing Li

item.title: Ukraine Says Drones Struck Russian Battery Plant for Missiles
item.description: Ukraine said its drones hit production facilities of a company that makes batteries used to power Russian missiles.
item.dc:creator: Kateryna Chursina, Aliaksandr Kudrytski

media:content.media:description: Yelets, Lipetsk region, Russia.

item.title: Trump Attack on Harvard Students Reverberates Across World
item.description: The Trump administration’s sudden move to bar foreign students at Harvard University is seen as dealing a blow to the US’s standing in business — and handing an advantage to elite rival colleges across the English-speaking world.
item.dc:creator: Bei Hu, Patpicha Tanakasempipat, Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: The Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Photographer: Mel Musto/Bloomberg

item.title: US Tariff Countdown Heats Up Race to Turn Talks Into Deals
item.description: Halfway through President Donald Trump’s 90-day freeze on his so-called reciprocal tariffs, a persistent gripe from businesses, consumers and governments facing them is severe uncertainty. The next 45 days may not provide much relief from the fog.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Leonard, Brendan Murray

media:content.media:description: The Wan Hai 331 container ship, operated by Wan Hai Line Ltd., right, and Posorja Express container ship, operated by Hapag-Lloyd AG, moored at a shipping terminal in Yokohama, Japan, on Tuesday, April 15, 2025. Japan is scheduled to release trade figures on April 17.

item.title: Harvard Sues US Over Trump’s International Student Ban
item.description: Harvard University sued the Trump administration over its move to block the school from enrolling international students, ratcheting up a high-stakes legal fight with broad implications for higher education in the US.
item.dc:creator: Janet Lorin

media:content.media:description: The Baker Library of the Harvard Business School on the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

item.title: US Considering Pulling Some Troops From South Korea, WSJ Reports
item.description: The US denied a media report that Washington is reviewing a proposal to withdraw some of its forces stationed in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Shinhye Kang

media:content.media:description: A soldier with the US Army Second Infantry Division uses a binocular during a joint live-fire exercise with the South Korea Army at Rodriguez complex in Pocheon, South Korea, on Monday, Feb. 10, 2025. North Korean leader Kim Jong Un blamed the military partnership between the US, Japan and South Korea, and their nuclear war simulation exercises, for causing conflict and raising a grave challenge to the security of his country during a speech in Pyongyang Saturday. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Iran and US Start Fifth Round of Nuclear Talks in Rome
item.description: Iran and the US have started their next round of talks on the Islamic Republic’s nuclear program, the semi-official Iranian Students’ News Agency reported.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Sykes

media:content.media:description: Iran's Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi

item.title: Poland Says Intercepted Russian Su-24 Bomber Over Baltic Sea
item.description: Poland intercepted and deterred a Russian bomber aircraft over the Baltic Sea late on Thursday, according to Defense Minister Wladyslaw Kosiniak-Kamysz.
item.dc:creator: Piotr Bujnicki

media:content.media:description: A Su-24 aircraft in Moscow.

item.title: EU Agrees to Reinstate Trade Quotas on Ukraine as War Drags on
item.description: The European Union has agreed to reinstate quotas on imports of several agricultural goods from Ukraine, adding to the challenges faced by its war-hit economy.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Volodymyr Verbianyi

media:content.media:description: The summer wheat harvest in the Fastiv district of Kyiv region, Ukraine. Photographer: Andrew Kravchenko/Bloomberg

item.title: Protesters Yell ‘Shame’ at Guests of Trump’s Memecoin Dinner
item.description: Top holders of Donald Trump’s memecoin and other guests were greeted by protesters as they arrived for a dinner with the president at his golf club outside of Washington on Thursday, a day which saw Bitcoin extend its record high amid optimism about US government support for the crypto industry.
item.dc:creator: Olga Kharif, Zeke Faux

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators shout outside Trump National Golf Course in Sterling, Virginia, on May 22, 2025. US President Donald Trump is attending a private dinner at his club for the top 220 buyers of his memecoin $TRUMP. (Photo by Jim WATSON / AFP) (Photo by JIM WATSON/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: South African Police Minister Debunks Trump’s Genocide Claim
item.description: South Africa’s police minister rejected the false conspiracy theory spread by US President Donald Trump that White farmers are being subjected to a genocide, saying it is “totally unsubstantiated.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Cohen

media:content.media:description: Senzo Mchunu.

item.title: Russia Douses Trump’s Desire for Pope to Host Ukraine Talks
item.description: The US and European leaders are placing their hopes in the Vatican to engage Russia and Ukraine in peace talks, after President Donald Trump said Pope Leo XIV had expressed interest in the idea. The Kremlin isn’t so keen.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sills

media:content.media:description: Pope Leo XIV at St Peter's Square in The Vatican on May 21.

item.title: Bulgaria Is on Track to Win EU Approval to Join the Euro Next Year
item.description: Bulgaria is close to clearing a major hurdle toward euro adoption, putting the Black Sea nation on course to join the currency area next year.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Viktoria Dendrinou, Slav Okov

media:content.media:description: Sofia, Bulgaria.

item.title: US Debt Limit Nail-Biter Looms as Senate Ponders Trump Tax Bill
item.description: Chances of a close brush with a US payment default are growing as the Senate plans for time-consuming revisions to President Donald Trump’s sprawling, multi-trillion-dollar tax and spending package.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Chris Cioffi, Alex Harris

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC. Photographer: Annabelle Gordon/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump’s War on Harvard Is Good News for China
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Katia Dmitrieva

media:content.media:description: The Baker Library of the Harvard Business School on the Harvard University campus in Boston, Massachusetts, US, on Monday, May 5, 2025. President Donald Trump said Harvard University would lose its tax-exempt status, stepping up his attack on the Ivy League school with a threat that was decried as out of his jurisdiction. Photographer: Mel Musto/Bloomberg

item.title: RedBird Agrees to Buy Telegraph, Ending UK Newspaper’s Limbo
item.description: RedBird Capital Partners agreed to buy the Telegraph in a £500 million ($674 million) deal, ending two years of uncertainty for the UK newspaper group.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Nimmo

media:content.media:description: Front pages of the Daily Telegraph newspaper.

item.title: Trump Calls Japan’s Ishiba Ahead of Latest Tariff Talks
item.description: US President Donald Trump initiated a phone call with Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba and discussed tariffs in general terms, just as Tokyo’s top negotiator left for the US for another round of trade talks.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara, Akemi Terukina

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba, Japan's prime minister and president of the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), during the party's annual convention in Tokyo, Japan, on Sunday, March 9, 2025. Japan’s lower house passed the budget for the year starting in April, checking off a key item on Ishiba’s to-do-list for shoring up his leadership ahead of a national election in the summer.

item.title: Tycoon Mordashov’s Local Spat Signals Changing Elite in Russia
item.description: Alexey Mordashov, one of Russia’s richest men, has found an unexpected adversary in the governor of the region where his steelmaker, Severstal PJSC, operates, the latest illustration of the waning power of the country’s tycoons that’s been accelerated by the invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Liezel Hill

media:content.media:description: Alexey Mordashov Photographer: Olga Maltseva/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Turkey Bans Images of Jailed Istanbul Mayor in Growing Crackdown
item.description: Turkey banned the use of images depicting jailed Istanbul Mayor Ekrem Imamoglu and detained dozens of municipality staff, escalating a standoff with the opposition that’s unsettled investors.
item.dc:creator: Selcan Hacaoglu

media:content.media:description: The fallout from Istanbul Mayor Ekrem Imamoglu’s detention has reverberated through financial markets. Photographer: David Lombeida/Bloomberg

item.title: Suriname Elects New President to Navigate Its Impending Oil Boom
item.description: Suriname is heading to the polls in an election that will help shape how the South American country adapts to its newfound oil wealth.
item.dc:creator: Denis Chabrol, Fabiola Zerpa

media:content.media:description: The Staatsolie refinery in Wanica, Suriname.

item.title: Iran Says ‘Time to Decide’ Ahead of Nuclear Talks With US
item.description: Iran said it’s “time to decide” ahead of Friday’s nuclear talks with the US, with the main sticking point being whether Tehran will be able to continue enriching uranium.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Sykes

media:content.media:description: The Bushehr nuclear power plant in Bushehr province, Iran. Source: NurPhoto/NurPhoto

item.title: Poland’s Surging Stocks Tested by Neck-and-Neck Runoff Election
item.description: The slump in Polish stocks, one of the year’s global equity standouts, signals that traders are increasingly jittery about any more political surprises.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Krasuski

media:content.media:description: Stock prices and trading data on digital boards at Warsaw Stock Exchange in Warsaw, Poland, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Poland’s central bank cut interest rates for the first time since October 2023 as eastern Europe’s biggest economy prepares to elect a new president in a little over a week’s time.

item.title: Dutch Leader Says Trump Plans to Attend NATO Summit in June
item.description: Dutch Prime Minister Dick Schoof said President Donald Trump has confirmed that he planned to attend the North Atlantic Treaty Organization’s June summit in The Hague.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump on the South Lawn of the White House before boarding Marine One in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, April 25, 2025. The Trump administration is putting pressure on Europe to ditch a rulebook that would compel developers of advanced artificial intelligence to follow stricter standards of transparency, risk-mitigation and copyright rules.

item.title: US Bans Harvard From Enrolling Foreigners, Forcing Transfers
item.description: The Trump administration blocked Harvard University from enrolling international students, delivering a major blow to the school and escalating its fight with elite colleges to unprecedented levels.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron, Janet Lorin, Brooke Sutherland

media:content.media:description: Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

item.title: Zohran Mamdani, the Socialist Who Could Be NYC's New Mayor
item.description: Rent freezes, city-run grocery stores, and more Halal carts.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: Zohran Mamdani, New York City mayoral candidate, speaks during the United Federation of Teachers (UFT) mayoral forum in New York, US, on Saturday, May 17, 2025. The New York mayoral primary elections are scheduled to be held on June 24.

item.title: Marcos Keeps Philippine Economic Team, Replaces Top Diplomat
item.description: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. retained his economic managers in a sign of policy continuity amid a Cabinet shakeup, while replacing his top diplomat as tensions with China linger.
item.dc:creator: Andreo Calonzo, Ditas B Lopez

media:content.media:description: Ferdinand Marcos Jr., Philippines' president, speaks during a Bloomberg Television interview in Manila, the Philippines, on Tuesday, March 19, 2024. Marcos said the threat to his nation from China's sweeping claims in the South China Sea is growing but argued that his government's efforts to assert sovereignty over disputed areas aren't meant to start a conflict by "poking the bear." Photographer: Veejay Villafranca/Bloomberg

item.title: These World Leaders Went to Harvard Before Trump’s Foreign Student Ban
item.description: The Trump administration’s move to block Harvard University from enrolling international students doesn’t just put more financial pressure on the school but also threatens a cradle for global political leaders.
item.dc:creator: Foster Wong

media:content.media:description: Lawrence Wong Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg
